docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 2 The State Department is preparing a fresh set of regulations to clarify and tighten restrictions on travel to Cuba....
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 2 The State Department is preparing a fresh set of regulations to clarify and tighten restrictions on travel to Cuba.
docs.abstract: US prepares new travel regulations; present rules considered too 'vague' as basis for legal action; Repr Cramer urges probe of students trip; charges it was arranged to indoctrinate them in Communism; Sen subcom releases Apr '62 testimony of former Fair Play for Cuba aide R Taber, charged with using Cuban Govt funds to sponsor similar US student tours in '59 and '60; Sen Dodd notes how Taber, despite his record, was able to have passport renewed

headline.main: U.S. Tightening Ban On Travel to Cuba; U.S. IS TIGHTENING CUBA-TRAVEL BAN Investigation Sought

byline.original: By HENRY RAYMONT Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: John Masefield, the English poet, will be a passenger on board the White Star liner Olympic when it sails from West Seventeenth Street at midnight for Cherbourg and Southampton. He is accompanied by Mrs. Masefield. He arrived here last month to vi...
docs.lead_paragraph: John Masefield, the English poet, will be a passenger on board the White Star liner Olympic when it sails from West Seventeenth Street at midnight for Cherbourg and Southampton. He is accompanied by Mrs. Masefield. He arrived here last month to visit friends in this city and deliver six readings from his works at the New York School of Social Research.

docs.snippet: CONCEIVED as havens of tranquillity, national parks have recently been at issue in some noisy disputes. In just the last few months, two efforts to preserve or restore to the parks ''natural quiet'' -- widely defined as the absence of manmade soun...
docs.lead_paragraph: CONCEIVED as havens of tranquillity, national parks have recently been at issue in some noisy disputes. In just the last few months, two efforts to preserve or restore to the parks ''natural quiet'' -- widely defined as the absence of manmade sound -- has sparked legal and legislative fights. In the first instance, on Dec. 31, 1996, the Interior Department and the Federal Aviation Administration issued regulations affecting sightseeing flights over the Grand Canyon. The regulations, which took effect Thursday, cap the number of commercial aircraft that can fly over the canyon at 136, the size of the existing fleet, but do not limit the number of air tours each plane can fly. They also ban flights from sunset to dawn.
docs.abstract: Attempts by Interior Department, FAA, environmental groups and Sen John McCain to restore 'natural quiet' to Grand Canyon reviewed; operators of sightseeing flights protest (S)

headline.main: Lots of Noise Being Made Over Quiet in U.S. Parks
